title: Once we have filed bankruptcy years ago like about 6 years, can we file again
question: or can we not. would it be chapter 7 or chapter 13.
answers:
Someone needs to look up the date of the old case filing. Your eligibility to file a Ch 7 runs from the date you last filed, not from the discharge date.

If you can't do a 7, you might still be able to get results similar to a 7 by filing Chapter 13.

A personal consultation with a lawyer who specializes in BK will be very helpful for you. At least you will learn your options.
If you don't meet the eight year time frame for a chapter 7, you can always file a chapter 13 and then convert it to a chapter 7 after the eight years has passed.

Assuming that you received a discharge a discharge in the prior Chapter 7 case, you would be eligible to file a subsequent Chapter 7 case eight years and one day after the date on which you filed the earlier case.

You would be eligible to file a Chapter 13 case in which you would be granted a discharge even if you paid less than 100% of the creditor claims if you await four years and one day after the filing date of the earlier case. This would be what is called a "full discharge Chapter 13".

And even if neither four years or eight years have run, you are still eligible to file a Chapter 13 case, but there would be no discharge granted. This would be what is called a "non-discharging Chapter 13". Such cases simply give you the opportunity to stay (hold off) creditors and make payments for up to 60 months based upon your ability to pay, even if that will not pay the full amount of the debt. In such a case, upon conclusion of the Chapter 13 plan, you would then still of the remaining unpaid debt.
If you received a discharge in the first case, it is too soon to receive a discharge in a new chapter 7 case. You are currently eligible to receive a discharge in a chapter 13 case.
